title: Friday, 15th January, 2016
bodyHTML:
11:00 am
PM

Morning

PM

Roiled Markets Live

PM

Gone out of fashion, hasn't it, the word roiled

11:01 am
PM

But i like roiled

PM

It's short and to the point

PM

I think, rather than use a smarty pants picture today, we just go for a couple of tin hats

11:02 am
PM

tinhat tinhat

PM

There

PM

Suits the mood

11:02 am
PM

And make sure those chin straps are fastened

BE

Agreed.

PM

What are we down currently Bryce? 1.3%?

11:03 am
PM

Footsie wise

PM

No let up

PM

Miners

11:04 am

Oh boy

Yeah, miners. Trading like small caps.

PM

Reality dawns

11:04 am
PM

Do we go straight into BHP?

PM

http://www.investe...1601150700099582L/

PM

11:05 am
PM

Acknowledgement of the fact

PM

Inevitable step on the road to recovery etc

BE

In the bite-the-bullet sense? Yes, guess so.

11:05 am

Ah yea, that

BHP Billiton PLC (BLT:LSE): Last: 619.90, down 37.1 (-5.65%), High: 645.70, Low: 613.40, Volume: 6.73m
BE

Screens showing -- based on BHP's guidance -- a yield on that of about 13%.

PM

hahaha

11:07 am
PM

Junk equity

BE

We did this with Anglo, of course, but there's a reason to repeat it. When do companies have to tell shareholders they won't be getting the divi previously indicated?

PM

Can't answer that

11:08 am
BE

Clearly, market's already priced in the $7.2bn we had written off today.

BE

But it seems a bit blinkered to not read that through to the divi and its likelihood of being paid.

PM

Maybe they just want to split up the news

11:09 am
PM

Into manageable chunks

PM

Provide us with a flow of copy

BE

Yeah, not make it look like a kitchen sink.

11:09 am
PM

Rather than following the first rule of a crisis

PM

which is to get all your bad news out, fast and in one go

BE

And I guess there's no kitchen sink big enough here. It's more a swimming pool.

11:10 am
BE

Let me get some sellside to talk us through the implications.

PM

On the the up side, I see they are actually cutting onshore production

PM

a bit

11:10 am
PM

But yeah, sell side

BE

Cazenove as good as any.

BE

BHP has announced a $7.2bn pre-tax ($4.9bn post tax) impairment on the
carrying value of its US Onshore assets, taking total impairments against
the assets to ~$13bn. BHP’s revised reported carrying value of $12bn (net
a $4bn deferred tax liability) compares against JPMe $10.6bn NPV, we
therefore expect further impairments are still likely. This has negative
implications for group gearing which we estimate at ~35% by Jun’16E
(post this impairment). Whilst gearing is not a core financial metric
observed by credit rating agencies, we believe it remains an important
symbolic assessment of capital adequacy. In our view, this carries wider
implications for the progressive policy and BHP’s capital adequacy. We
currently expect a 50% rebasing of the progressive dividend at the Aug'16
results

11:10 am
BE

August 2016 before the divi's rebased!?

BE

Why?!

BE

And Merrill

11:12 am
BE

oday BHP took a $7.2b pre-tax charge to the carrying value of its US Onshore Shale
business. Further, the company has taken down its rig-count to 5 (from 7) for the 3rd
quarter of 2016 with investment and development plans under review with a focus on
preserving cash. To us these decisions make sense and are outlined in our recent note
here where we concluded that despite making strong gains in capital productivity, the
business was running hard to stand still given weak oil and gas prices. What ’s more
important is the implications of lower production past FY16, where at current forward
prices all but the highest quality Black Hawk acreage looks uneconomic in our view – we
lower our US Onshore production by 7Mmboe (6%) in FY17.

BE

By taking down the rig count, we see further pressure on production in FY17 for BHP.
Already, we expect gas production to wane, but now liquids production is likely to fall as
well. From our previous FY17 total group production estimate of 244mmboe, we now
reset our forecasts to 237mmboe, essentially flat vs FY16 and 3% lower versus our prior
estimate. The new $16b ($12b once adjusted for tax liabilities) US Onshore carrying
value represents a more optimistic outlook vs the forward curve in our view, but remains
in-line with our $12.8b base case NPV for this business. Valuation bookends remain wide
with a scenario of spot prices forever yielding $222m and $2.3b on the forward curve.

BE

What’s next?
BHP is currently focused on exploration in order to replenish much needed reserves for
their conventional portfolio – M&A remains a viable option as well. On a 2P basis and
based on FY15 production, the portfolio reserve life appears to be 25yrs. However,
breaking this down, BHP's reserve life in US Onshore Gas is 48yrs, 17yrs in US Onshore
Oil, 15yrs for Australia and 11yrs in Gulf of Mexico.
New forecasts
Putting through our new forecasts, we have cut underlying EBITDA by approximately
1.5% in FY17-FY18. Reported profit is impacted by the $7.2b ($4.9b post-tax) charge.

11:13 am
BE

Hey, speaking of Merrill.

BE

Interesting sector note from Jason Fairclough this morning

PM

Go on

11:14 am
BE

He's been arguing for some time that the entire sector needs rights issues. His previous estimate was $50bn required, I think.

BE

It's now $69bn.

PM

ouch

11:14 am
BE

That's to reset the sector to 2x EBITDA, which is the minimum really.

BE

Fairclough's argument is that cash calls would signal the bottom of the market.

BE

Which they did in 2009, when Rio raised $15bn and Xstrata raised $9bn

11:15 am
BE

Though one can argue whether 2009 can be seen as the bottom of the market when there's another bottom six years later.

PM

I note this line from the BHP statement

PM

Beyond this, investment and development plans for the remainder of the 2016 financial year are under review, with a focus on preserving cash flow.

11:15 am
PM

So if they need to replenish reserves they are going to have to do something

PM

Cash calls and consolidation perhaps

BE

Well, as we've written a lot, the consensus now says a 50% divi cut and about a third off capex I think.

11:16 am
BE

Management has been pretty clear about preserving the credit rating above all else.

PM

Indeed

BE

Anyway, back to Merrill's "cash calls will save us" argument.

11:17 am
BE

A key discussion we’ve had with a few investors (and corporates) is whether the best
policy isn’t to just “muddle through”. For companies with limited near-term maturities
and ample liquidity (such as Anglo and Teck) this must seem like a tempting option. If a
company did manage to “hold on” and the cycle turned, leveraged returns for equity
holders should result. For us, the danger with this approach is potential “Zombification”.

BE

Put simply, with too much financial leverage, equity gets crushed in a longer than expected
down market, leaving companies run on a “shoe string” instead of run for value. No capital
is available to make appropriate and value accretive investments. We think the US coal
industry is a case in point; e.g. Peabody (not covered) has US$75 mn mkt cap on debt of
US$6 bn. Too much leverage can also add financial stress during unexpected events, e.g. Samarco tragedy.

BE

We consider the famous mining finance axiom: “Raise money when you can, not when
you need to”. Would investors be supportive of equity raises right now? If framed
correctly, we think the answer is “Yes”. Certainly, discussions with investors post our
BHP RIO consolidation note (6 Jan 2016) indicated that a number of them would support
balance sheet strengthening, “definitive” equity raises. Put another way, we think that
investors interested in making a value call are deterred by 1) China macro and 2)
overleveraged balance sheets. While China macro looks likely to remain something of
an X factor, we think that fixing balance sheets “definitively” might encourage long term
value investors to buy early and “wait out” near term volatility.

11:17 am
BE

So, here come the numbers.

BE

BE

As in, Anglo and Vale need to raise at least twice their market cap

11:18 am
PM

Brilliant

BE

Glencore needs about 100%. Teck needs nearly 300% of its cap.

PM

That's be a breeze

BE

Yeah, we should do that more. Though the really bad decisions usually fall to previous management, so it can look a bit churlish.

11:21 am

Rather than going back, looking at the presentations, looking at the execs who made the decisions

PM

Maybe churlish

Though I guess, given Cynthia Carroll still runs a mining company (of sorts, kinda) it's worth mentioning.

11:22 am
BE

Anyway, people seem to be connecting yesterday's Anglo rally with the idea that it might exit South Africa rather than pull a cash call.

BE

To be clear, management is unlikely to want to do either of these things.

PM

Entirely?

11:23 am
PM

All of Africa?

PM

S Africa

BE

Yeah, in specie distribution of Anglo Africa to AAL shareholders.

11:23 am
PM

Oh I see

PM

Like management just going "It's yours"

BE

It sort-of makes sense. But clearly, it's not easy and the benefits aren't immediate beyond political.

11:24 am
BE

What it's do is turn Anglo ex-SA into a bid candidate.

PM

Yeah, i see that

BE

Perhaps for the likes of BHP, one assumes, when it has to give a reason on why it's pulling a gigantic rights issue after spinning off some of its most cash-generative businesses into a misshapen lump called S32.

11:25 am
BE

Anyway, wasn't there a GS note on comms today as well?

PM

Yeah, let me share

PM

10 points on the marginalisation of commodities

11:26 am
PM

1.

Most of the material declines in spot commodity prices have already occurred. Yes, from a trading perspective, an oil move from $30/bbl to $20/bbl would be a significant 33% decline, but given that relative prices are what matter in the real economy to consumers and oil producing nations, such a move is far less economically important than it was even a year ago. This also changes the inflationary/deflationary impact that commodity prices can have on price levels as they are simply a smaller share of the consumption basket. More importantly, this shifts the emphasis of the market from material price moves to material fundamental adjustments in 2016. Thus far, fundamental adjustments across the commodity complex have been relatively small. In oil, most of the demand improvement to lower prices occurred in 2015, and non-US supply reductions have been extremely modest, while in the US supply is only down about 150,000 b/d yoy as of year-end. In metals, supply has yet to materially come off as it is simply too easy to store excess output. What this suggests is that the key theme for 2016 will be real fundamental adjustments that can rebalance markets to create the birth of a new bull market, which we still see happening in late 2016.

PM

2.

It is important to emphasize that the recent decline in commodity prices is not the result of cyclical demand weakness but rather is the result of a continuation of structural supply and macro forces from 2013. Reflecting the structural nature of recent price declines, nearly all the decline in energy and metal prices has been driven by long-dated prices. Since December last year, long-dated oil prices are down nearly $10/bbl versus the spot price down $11/bbl, which is in an indication that weak oil fundamentals only played a small role in the most recent downdraft. In addition, the long-dated oil and copper prices adjusted for producer country FX are mostly unchanged, which underscores the macro nature of the recent declines. Importantly, even if this decline was growth related, our estimate of oil demand price elasticity suggests that the year-to-date decline in prices has been sufficiently large to fully offset a 0.5% decline in global GDP growth to 3.0% from 3.5%, leaving the fundamental oil balance unchanged.

PM

3.

Driving this recent macro re-pricing across the commodity complex are the same three themes we focused on last year (the 3D’s of macro): D eflation (due to excess investment in commodity production), D ivergence (in US economic growth and hence a stronger US dollar) and D eleveraging (rebalancing of China and EM economies which slows potential growth). In December and early January, the 3D’s fired on all cylinders. The Fed raised rates due to strong payroll numbers. OPEC reconfirmed the deflationary pressures of the New Oil Order just as large scale mining projects in places like Peru pressed ahead despite lower prices. This all fueled more pressure on commodity and EM currencies, pushing the US dollar trade weighted index (TWI) to the highest levels since 2002. By early January, the resulting pressure on the Chinese CNY brought to the forefront the structural issues that still face China in terms of deleveraging (in Q3, credit growth of 12.5% yoy remained stubbornly above nominal GDP growth of 6.2% yoy) and the required rebalancing from heavy industry (favoring capex commodity demand) towards domestic consumption (favoring opex commodity demand). If 2013 was characterized by the ‘taper tantrum’ (Divergence) and 2014 by the shift in OPEC policy (Deflation), then 2015 was characterized by the Chinese CNY devaluation (Deleveraging) when China joined the 3D’s of macro.

11:26 am
PM

Let me speed this up

PM

All of this helped to act as a drag on global manufacturing. Although this is nothing new, the negative feedback loop continued to pressure commodity prices lower, the dollar higher and create broader growth concerns stemming from a weakening in global manufacturing. However, we believe the growth concerns about the broader economy are likely exaggerated by the moves in financial markets as physical commodity demand shows no material deterioration from recent levels, even for metals in China. While this does create some near-term upside price risk, it doesn’t change the longer-term need for lower commodity prices to create real physical supply adjustments. We believe ‘financial’ volatility relative to ‘real’ physical volatility in fundamentals has increased over the past decade due to: 1) greater FX flexibility with very few commodity producers still relying on US dollar pegs (only the GCC countries still have pegs), 2) more global trade in commodities and other physical goods, and 3) deeper and more liquid commodity and macro markets to lay off capital risk.

5.

FX flexibility can offset terms of trade shocks more quickly than in the past, helping smooth the required physical (supply and trade) adjustments over time. This is most evident where flexible exchange rates allow producers such as Russia to absorb the terms of trade shock through a swift devaluation, leaving oil prices in producers’ local currencies nearly unchanged since 2014. This allows them to maintain output if costs are also in local terms, reducing the need for an abrupt reduction in output and the associated economic ramifications. This in turn pushes the burden of adjustment onto the producers tied to the US dollar such as US shale and GCC oil producers. The relative cost competitiveness of the GCC producers suggests that US shale producers will have to bare most of the adjustment process, which is the basis of our fundamental outlook in 2016 with US Lower 48 production expected to decline by 575,000 b/d this year, pushing the oil market into a deficit during 2H16. Ironically, over the previous decade it was the dollar denominated US consumer that balanced the shortages while this decade it is the dollar denominated US producer that will likely balance the surpluses.

BE

(@pfd: yes, in theory.)

11:27 am
PM

The second shift that increases financial volatility while reducing real physical volatility is the growth in global trade that characterized the previous decade. This creates more potential outlets for surplus commodity production, including more downstream and finished commodities such as specialty chemicals and fabricated metals. With more outlets including storage, excess production can be maintained on a longer time horizon before surpluses saturate markets and breach logistical and storage constraints that can create an outright collapse in commodity prices, which is the basis of our $20/bbl oil scenario. While the surplus in oil continues to pressure oil timespreads wider and reversed the WTI-Brent spread as European surpluses are moved to the US Gulf Coast where spare storage exists, we still aren’t adopting the $20/bbl scenario as our baseline forecast since balances have not deteriorated further following our mid-December update. Barring a supply or demand/weather shock that shifts the balance by more than 340,000 b/d we don’t see the oil market hitting storage capacity constraints, which is why we are maintain our $40/bbl WTI price forecast for 1H16.

7.

The third shift is deeper and more liquid commodity markets to lay off capital risk, which allows producers to help smooth the physical adjustment at the expense of increased downside price volatility. While hedge ratios were on the low side going into this most recent sell off, the industry was more hedged than in say 1998/99. And clearly during the most recent sell off, some producers sold forward more production while others likely used inventory monetization programs as a way to deal with unproductive assets, which helped push forwards lower. However, with all of calendar 2016 below $40/bbl, such selling pressures are likely to slow except for low cash cost players or extremely financially dire situations. Historically, bear markets typically end with the back-end selling off several months after spot prices have reached the bottom. A flat curve near cash costs is historically the buy signal for passive investors and we believe the current bear market will end the same way and such a signal is what will shift us to being bullish commodities.

PM

Real fundamental adjustments have always taken time due to physical frictions inherent in supply chains, labor contracts, and the opportunity costs associated with shutting down a mine, field or plant. This is the basis of real option theory, which argues that prices will likely overshoot financial costs to the downside before producers have an incentive to reduce output. And, just as in oil, metal prices have recently dropped below our targets suggested by financial economics. In the short term, stretched bearish positioning is already pricing in fundamental weakness. Catalysts for short covering could include a seasonal demand pick up post the Chinese New year, the likelihood of El Nino driven Zambian supply disruptions, and potential further price related capacity closures. Medium term though, there are clearly downside risks to copper prices – namely a major Chinese devaluation or oil prices falling sharply owing to operational constraints – although these developments are not our base case. Meanwhile, we remain bearish on all-in aluminium pricing on the back of anticipated ongoing market surplus and cost deflation (Chinese costs of production are much lower than the market generally recognizes), and see the risks surrounding our current forecasts as heavily skewed to the downside.

9.

Recent events in Saudi Arabia and Iran have raised the question of geopolitical events creating a supply disruption that rebalances the market more quickly than expected. We still see such an event as a remote possibility. It is important to emphasize that geopolitically generated supply disruptions are generally the result of a civil war that physically disrupts output, as no one wants to lose the revenue. Civil war examples include Iran (1978/79), Venezuela (2002), and Libya (2011). Barring a civil war, such supply disruptions have little precedent. In fact, the opposite holds in the current environment as recent events in the Middle East have reinforced national tendencies and this would only reinforce the producers to increase output to maximize revenue to support the state. So we stand by our view that while geopolitical risks have never been higher, oil supplies at risk have never been lower, particularly given how much supply is already offline.

10.

While we clearly don’t take a strong stand on spot commodity prices from these levels, we do take a strong view on selling longer-dated commodity prices today. Furthermore, we will turn bullish once the forward curves flatten, as we expect later this year in energy, to incentivize inventories back into the market to accommodate expected deficits. In the meantime, however, the fundamental shifts in energy and metals supply that we believe need to happen will likely occur in three phases: 1) the survival phase, which we just ended with the capitulation of several large offshore producers this week, 2) the inflection phase, which we are now entering, where the least fit producers engage in significant capital restructuring, including the sale if possible or potential shuttering of assets, and 3) eventually the regeneration phase of a new industry with stranded assets ultimately shuttered or optimized. We believe the inflection phase will characterize 1H16; however, once it happens we will likely move quickly into a period where inventories draw and forward curves flatten. At what price level this occurs is still wide open to debate, and we believe the 3D’s will continue to create downside risks until commodity supply adjustments break the negative feedback loop and start the path towards balanced markets.

PM

Done

11:28 am
undefined
BE

So what else aside from miners?

BE

Fantasy M&A, maybe?

11:28 am
PM

Sure

BE

Unilever, again.

Unilever PLC (ULVR:LSE): Last: 2,795, down 25.5 (-0.90%), High: 2,833, Low: 2,780, Volume: 816.62k
11:01 am
PM

Welcome to Markets Live

BE

Which is rumour that comes around ever few months, and has done for the past decade.

BE

Exane's argument is that Unilever CEO Paul Polman is hitting the seven year itch and needs something big

11:30 am
BE

Meanwhile, Colgate's never been cheaper

BE

Buying Colgate would be massive for cost cutting

BE

As in, gigantic. As in 16% of Colgate sales.

11:31 am
BE

Plus the tax angle, as it'd be "an inverse inversion"

BE

(Yeah, really. I've not read that bit of the note yet so I'm not sure how an inverse inversion would work.)

BE

So ....... get the deal done before the cheap credit window closes, says Exane

11:32 am
BE

To our mind there is one buyer for Colgate and that is Unilever. If Unilever is ever going to be brave, now is the perfect time.

BE

All of which they present as a listicle.

BE

7 reasons why Unilever should buy Colgate now

11:32 am
BE

(No gifs though.)

BE

1) Unilever is now fit to acquire
Reflecting upon Unilever’s recent investor seminar in Singapore/Manila, we were struck
by one thing: we have never previously encountered such sharpness, clarity and
alignment of strategy at Unilever. The internal impediments to growth are gone. In
short, Unilever is in rude organisational health and able to undertake a transformational
deal.

BE

2) Colgate’s operational performance is showing signs of strain
While headline operational metrics at Colgate remain relatively impressive, all is not
quite as good as it seems. To be more specific, LFL sales growth is likely being
materially boosted by continued SICAD accounting for Venezuela and gross margin
progression has effectively plateaued (FY15e gross margin will be in-line with FY09
levels).

11:33 am
BE

3) Colgate has steadily de-rated relative to Unilever
As highlighted in the figure below, Colgate has steadily de-rated relative to Unilever:

BE

BE

(Charts. But not gifs.)

11:33 am
BE

4) The cost savings would be incredible
Given the incredibly good fit between the two businesses, our analysis (we outline in
detail within) suggests that cost savings from a Unilever-Colgate combination would be
truly eye-watering. To be more specific, we believe that the majority of Colgate’s ‘other
SG&A’ could effectively be restructured out. In aggregate, we estimate eventual
savings of 16% of sales.

BE

5) Tax efficiencies would likely be very material
Being US tax domiciled, but having the majority of its earnings overseas, there is likely
a material financial incentive for Colgate to re-domicile. A Unilever acquisition would
achieve exactly this. In addition, the resultant leverage could be used to gear up in the
higher-tax jurisdictions (most notably the US). We believe it likely an acquisition would
likely be able to lower Colgate’s tax rate (FY16e: 31.5%) closer to Unilever’s level
(FY16e: 26.0%).

BE

What am I up to here? Oh, five. Two to go.

11:34 am
BE

6) We are at the bottom of the credit cycle
What better time to launch a largely debt-funded acquisition than the bottom of the
credit cycle? To give a feel as to potential rates, we note that ABI’s 2022 bonds are
currently trading at a c.3% yield. Note: we estimate that net debt/EBITDA post the SAB
deal will likely be in the 4.0x to 4.5x range.

BE

7) Management stars are aligned
Mindful that management can often be an impediment to acquisitions, we note that Ian
Cook has been CEO of Colgate since 2007 and is now approaching 64 years of age.
Like Paul Polman, Ian Cook may well be starting to give thought to his own legacy and
future plans. Wouldn’t Chairman of Unilever be a nice role to move into? (We are
mindful that Unilever’s current Chairman, Michael Treschow, will retire in April-2016.)
As an aside, we estimate that Ian Cook would walk away with around USD227m in the
event of a take-over (USD90m over the current estimated value of his stock/option
holdings).

BE

All of which fits neatly into a broader theme.

11:36 am
BE

Which is partly a readthrough from Inbev, I suspect, where everyone says "which are the other four-into-three industries?"

BE

But also, there has been talk for quite a quile that Reckitt is up to something.

BE

Such as looking to buy Pfizer's consumer healthcare business.

11:36 am
BE

Or being the host body into which Pfizer reverses the whole of its run-off unit.

BE

Or, possibly, being the buyer of one of Glaxo's businesses.

BE

All speculation, to be clear. I don't know. The advisers Reckitt's paying a lot of mioney to might have thought of all, more or fewer of these already.

11:38 am
BE

Since I remember, there was a Caz note earlier in the week that kicked about the Reckitt M&A theme.

BE

Recently, Reckitt CEO, Mr Kapoor2, has stated that Reckitt would consider acquiring
Pfizer’s Consumer Health business should it come for sale, though there has been no
comment from Pfizer that it will dispose of its OTC division. (Pfizer is covered by
our US colleague Chris Schott). We note that Pfizer is one of the two top 5 players in
OTC (along with J&J) not to have been involved in the consolidation of the OTC
market - the company has been focused to pursue a deal in the pharma industry. We
see a strong fit between the two OTC businesses given the complementarities
between sub segments, as Pfizer is active in similar categories as RB but with a
stronger emphasis on the USA: VMS (Brand: Centrum), Analgesics (Brand: Advil)
and Cough & Cold (Brand: Robitussin) portfolio (Advil 15% share in the US market,
Robitussin 3% share in the US, Centrum 2% share in the US/ WE).

BE

According to its 2014 annual report, Pfizer Consumer Health (OTC) had revenues of
US$3.4bn or c£2bn. Pfizer does not disclose margins in its OTC business but we
note that the average disclosed margin for the main OTC players in FY14 was around
c19%, which would theoretically put Pfizer’s FY14 EBIT at around £380m, while
the average D&A for the industry is 2%, yielding an EBITDA average margin of
21%.

11:38 am
BE

In view of recent transaction multiples in the OTC industry with a wide
range of 4.5-6.5x sales multiples, this could theoretically suggest a potential price
range of £9bn-13bn for this business. Under such a scenario, this could potentially be
7-11% accretive to Reckitt assuming an all-debt deal on the average of the theoretical
price range (and 3% interest rate, 10% synergies and 23% tax rate, as previously
forecast for Reckitt). We believe that in such a scenario, Reckitt should be able to
finance this from leverage (pushing the leverage to 4.5x proforma), though we also
flagged in our September report that the Foods and Home division could be seen as
potential disposal candidates, fetching respectively £0.9-1.2bn and £3.5-4.5bn

PM

That's quite a lump of fantasy M&A

BE

(@cheecky: Indeed. I believe Robey won't even look at you if you're sub $10bn these days.)

11:40 am
BE

Yeah, I figured it was interesting. As hypothetical mergers of toothpaste and bleach go.

undefined
BE

Oh, while on the M&A theme .....

11:41 am
PM

(WhenIWereYoung -- dunno where you live, but i have that in Greenwich. It's a sign of people buying houses/flats and not actually living in them)

BE

Should just note the non-denial denial yesterday afternoon from WebMD.

PM

What did they say?

11:41 am
BE

"not currently in any negotiations to be acquired"

BE

After we reported it was exploring a sale, of course: http://www.ft.com/...-8a339b6f2164.html

PM

So pens down? Or no direct talks?

11:42 am
BE

Yeah, though I'm unclear on the pens down process in the US.

PM

Good story that

BE

Yeah. Looks like we went in a little too early and screwed up the process.

11:43 am
BE

Oops. Oh well.

BE

Let me get Cowen & Co to talk us though the deal that is not currently happening, currently.

BE

Recently, an FT article broke news that WBMD was in talks with potential buyers
including WBA or UNH, amongst others. WBMD could be looking to sell some or
all its business, or remain independent. Last year WBMD had also hired bankers to
explore a sale, but ultimately decided to remain independent. We do not find this
news particularly surprising, given we thought there might be speculation a deal was
in the works since the recent run-up in the stock post-3Q earnings on very limited
news flow. Our back of the envelope analysis suggests WBA or UNH could pay
around $65/share for WBMD, or about 14-15x EBITDA (including NOLs) and
still make the deal slightly accretive. Regardless, the acquisition would not be
